message.content:
Research the latest Vercel deployment configuration for web projects.

Find:
1. vercel.json configuration format
2. Current CLI commands and flags
3. Environment variable setup
4. Build and output settings
5. Any recent breaking changes

Note: This is for potential web dashboard/admin panel deployment alongside the UXP plugin.

Return exact configs and commands - no lengthy explanations.

content.text: I'll research the latest Vercel deployment configuration and commands.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Vercel environment variables setup 2025"

Links: [{"title":"Environment variables","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/environment-variables"},{"title":"How do I add environment variables to my Vercel project?","url":"https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-to-add-vercel-environment-variables"},{"title":"Environment Variables UI - Vercel","url":"https://vercel.com/blog/environment-variables-ui"},{"title":"How do I set up a staging environment on Vercel?","url":"https://vercel.com/kb/guide/set-up-a-staging-environment-on-vercel"},{"title":"System environment variables","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/environment-variables/system-environment-variables"},{"title":"Environments","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/deployments/environments"},{"title":"vercel env","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/cli/env"},{"title":"Framework environment variables","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/environment-variables/framework-environment-variables"},{"title":"Managing environment variables","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/environment-variables/managing-environment-variables"},{"title":"Optimize the Organization of Vercel Environment Variables for Your Project | Fishtank","url":"https://www.getfishtank.com/insights/optimize-the-organization-of-vercel-environment-variables-for-your-project"}]

Here's what I found about setting up environment variables in Vercel (2025):

## Adding Environment Variables

You can add Environment Variables to your site through Project Settings.(no content)These values can be used during builds or inside functions to read API keys, connect to your database, and more.(no content)Values are encrypted at rest and permission to view values can be restricted based on your role.

## Setting Up via Dashboard

To configure an Environment Variable for your project, simply navigate to your Project Settings and look for the newly added Environment Variables section.(no content)Within this section, you can assign an Environment Variable to the Production, Preview, or Development Environment, depending on where you want it to be available.

## Using the CLI

You can use `vercel env add` and `vercel env remove` to add or remove Environment Variables from your project, directly from the command-line.(no content)Environment Variables specified for the Development Environment are made available to your team and can be downloaded into a local development setup using the `vercel env pull` command, which automatically creates a .env file. At least version 18.0.0 of Vercel CLI is required to be able to run this command.

## Important Notes

Ensure that after adding a new Environment Variable, you have redeployed your application. Environment Variables are made available to the app on each deployment. If you attempt to read an Environment Variable that was added after the deployment was made, its value will be undefined.

## System Environment Variables

System environment variables are automatically populated by Vercel, such as the URL of the deployment or the name of the Git branch deployed. These include variables like `VERCEL_ENV`, `VERCEL_URL`, `VERCEL_GIT_COMMIT_REF`, and more.

## Framework-Specific Variables

Framework environment variables are automatically populated by Vercel, based on your project's framework. For example, Next.js projects get variables prefixed with `NEXT_PUBLIC_`, and Nuxt projects get variables prefixed with `NUXT_ENV_`.

## Custom Environments (Pro/Enterprise)

Vercel provides the option for Pro and Enterprise users to set up a custom environment that can be configured through the dashboard and be used as staging.(no content)With custom environments, you can use branch rules to automatically deploy your branch when the branch name matches the rule, attach a domain to your environment, set environment variables, or import environment variables from another environment.

## Shared Environment Variables

The cool thing with Vercel is that you can easily manage environment variables as complex as selecting only a number of projects it's going to appear on. Easily manage environment variables in Vercel by linking them to multiple projects.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.title: How do I add environment variables to my Vercel project?
How do I set up a staging environment on Vercel?
Optimize the Organization of Vercel Environment Variables for Your Project | Fishtank

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Vercel vercel.json configuration 2025 official documentation"

Links: [{"title":"Configuring projects with vercel.json","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration"},{"title":"Configuring a Build","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/builds/configure-a-build"},{"title":"Build Output Configuration","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/build-output-api/configuration"},{"title":"vercel.json file. -it allows you to define settings and… | by Naman Ahuja | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@palindromicnamed/the-vercel-json-9bdb33938ef3"},{"title":"Git Configuration","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/git-configuration"},{"title":"vercel.json. -the vercel.json file in a backend… | by Naman Ahuja | Medium","url":"https://medium.com/@palindromicnamed/vercel-json-c6101c98e5c2"},{"title":"Project settings","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/project-settings"},{"title":"Advanced Configuration","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/functions/configuring-functions/advanced-configuration"},{"title":"Mastering vercel.json with Frontend Backend Projects on Vercel","url":"https://peerlist.io/mahmudrahman/articles/mastering-verceljson-a-beginnerfriendly-guide-to-vercel-conf"},{"title":"Configuring Functions","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/functions/configuring-functions"}]

Here are the search results for Vercel vercel.json configuration documentation:

## Official Vercel Documentation

### Main Configuration Guide
As of April 23, 2025, Fluid compute is enabled by default for new projects. The official Vercel documentation at [vercel.com/docs/project-configuration](https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration) covers:

- Custom response headers configuration - valid values include a list of header definitions, and you can configure custom response headers for static files, Vercel functions, and wildcard routes that match all routes.
- Ignored Build Step settings - this value overrides the Ignored Build Step in Project Settings. When the command exits with code 1, the build will continue. When the command exits with 0, the build is ignored.
- Vercel Function Region configuration - you can define the regions where your Vercel functions are executed. Users on Pro and Enterprise can deploy to multiple regions, while Hobby plans can select any single region.

### Project Settings
From the [Project Settings documentation](https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/project-settings):
You can define a vercel.json file at the project root that allows you to set and override the default behavior of your project.(no content)In your build and deployment settings, you can adjust configurations such as framework settings, code directory, and Node.js version.

### Git Configuration
The [Git Configuration page](https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration/git-configuration) explains how to specify branches that should not trigger a deployment upon commits. By default, any unspecified branch is set to deploy. Use minimatch syntax to define behavior for multiple branches.

### Build Configuration
Vercel automatically configures the build settings for many front-end frameworks, but you can also customize the build according to your requirements.

### Key Features of vercel.json
Based on the documentation, vercel.json allows you to configure:
- Build and output settings for your project, routing with custom routes, redirects, rewrites, and headers, environment variables for different environments (development, preview, production), and regions specifying which Vercel regions your functions should be deployed to.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "Vercel CLI commands deploy 2025 latest"

Links: [{"title":"Vercel CLI Overview","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/cli"},{"title":"vercel deploy","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/cli/deploy"},{"title":"Deploying Projects from Vercel CLI","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/cli/deploying-from-cli"},{"title":"Vercel","url":"https://vercel.com/kb/guide/how-to-alias-a-preview-deployment-using-the-cli"},{"title":"How can I use the Vercel CLI for custom workflows?","url":"https://vercel.com/kb/guide/using-vercel-cli-for-custom-workflows"},{"title":"Deploy to Vercel using the CLI | App Builder Docs","url":"https://appbuilder-docs.agora.io/turn-key/guides/frontend/Deploy-Without-1-Click"},{"title":"Deploy Command | vercel/vercel | DeepWiki","url":"https://deepwiki.com/vercel/vercel/3.2-deploy-command"},{"title":"CLI Commands and Help System | vercel/vercel | DeepWiki","url":"https://deepwiki.com/vercel/vercel/3.1-cli-commands"},{"title":"Vercel","url":"https://sandocs.vercel.app/docs/configuration/cli"},{"title":"Deploying to Vercel without linking a repository — Alex Chan","url":"https://www.alexchantastic.com/deploying-with-vercel-cli"}]

Based on the search results, here's the latest information on Vercel CLI deploy commands for 2025:

## Vercel CLI Deploy Commands

### Basic Deploy Commands

You can deploy your Vercel Projects from Vercel CLI using the `vercel` or `vercel deploy` commands.(no content)The Deploy Command is the primary user interface for deploying projects to the Vercel platform through the CLI. It orchestrates the entire deployment process from initial project validation through final deployment status reporting, serving as the default command when users invoke the Vercel CLI.

### Installation

Install the Vercel CLI using `npm i -g vercel`.

### Deployment Workflows

When using the Vercel CLI to do a deployment using the `vercel deploy` command, a successful deployment writes the deployed URL to the Standard Output so you can use it in later commands.

### Preview Deployments and Aliasing

You can use Vercel CLI to create Preview Deployments and can also use the Vercel CLI to alias a URL to that deployment. Each preview deployment has a unique URL. The latest Preview Deployment is automatically aliased to a URL, ensuring you'll have a stable URL pointing to the last Preview Deployment.

### Prebuilt Deployments

The `--prebuilt` flag will signal to the Vercel CLI that you have already built the project locally and only want to deploy those files (and not your source files) to Vercel. The Vercel CLI will spit out a preview URL.(no content)You can build your application locally (or in a pipeline) without giving Vercel access to the source code through `vercel build`. Vercel automatically detects your frontend framework and generates a `.vercel/output` folder conforming to the Build Output API specification.

### Production Deployments

You can deploy to production using the same commands, but with the `--prod` flag. When using the `--prod` flag with `vercel build`, the production environment variables will be used instead of the preview environment variables.

### CI/CD Integration

You can use the Vercel CLI with any CI/CD provider such as Azure DevOps to generate Preview Deployments for every git push and deploy to Production when code is merged into the main branch. This approach is useful for developers seeking full control over their CI/CD pipeline, those unable to use Vercel's Git integration or those with a trunk-based development workflow.

### Global Options

The `--cwd` option can be used to provide a working directory (that can be different from the current directory) when running CLI commands. This option can be a relative or absolute path.(no content)The `--debug` option, shorthand `-d`, can be used to provide a more verbose output when running CLI commands.

For the most comprehensive and up-to-date documentation, you can visit the official Vercel CLI documentation at [vercel.com/docs/cli](https://vercel.com/docs/cli).


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

## Vercel CLI Deploy Commands

### Basic Deploy Commands

You can deploy your Vercel Projects from Vercel CLI using the `vercel` or `vercel deploy` commands.(no content)The Deploy Command is the primary user interface for deploying projects to the Vercel platform through the CLI. It orchestrates the entire deployment process from initial project validation through final deployment status reporting, serving as the default command when users invoke the Vercel CLI.

### Installation

Install the Vercel CLI using `npm i -g vercel`.

### Deployment Workflows

When using the Vercel CLI to do a deployment using the `vercel deploy` command, a successful deployment writes the deployed URL to the Standard Output so you can use it in later commands.

### Preview Deployments and Aliasing

You can use Vercel CLI to create Preview Deployments and can also use the Vercel CLI to alias a URL to that deployment. Each preview deployment has a unique URL. The latest Preview Deployment is automatically aliased to a URL, ensuring you'll have a stable URL pointing to the last Preview Deployment.

### Prebuilt Deployments

The `--prebuilt` flag will signal to the Vercel CLI that you have already built the project locally and only want to deploy those files (and not your source files) to Vercel. The Vercel CLI will spit out a preview URL.(no content)You can build your application locally (or in a pipeline) without giving Vercel access to the source code through `vercel build`. Vercel automatically detects your frontend framework and generates a `.vercel/output` folder conforming to the Build Output API specification.

### Production Deployments

You can deploy to production using the same commands, but with the `--prod` flag. When using the `--prod` flag with `vercel build`, the production environment variables will be used instead of the preview environment variables.

### CI/CD Integration

You can use the Vercel CLI with any CI/CD provider such as Azure DevOps to generate Preview Deployments for every git push and deploy to Production when code is merged into the main branch. This approach is useful for developers seeking full control over their CI/CD pipeline, those unable to use Vercel's Git integration or those with a trunk-based development workflow.

content.content:
Web search results for query: "vercel deploy command flags --prod --build-env 2025"

Links: [{"title":"vercel deploy","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/cli/deploy"},{"title":"Vercel CLI Overview","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/cli"},{"title":"Deploy Command | vercel/vercel | DeepWiki","url":"https://deepwiki.com/vercel/vercel/3.2-deploy-command"},{"title":"Environments","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/deployments/environments"},{"title":"Managing Deployments","url":"https://vercel.com/docs/deployments/managing-deployments"},{"title":"Pass environment variables to the vercel CLI build command - Help - Vercel Community","url":"https://community.vercel.com/t/pass-environment-variables-to-the-vercel-cli-build-command/10653"},{"title":"Per-environment and per-branch Build Commands on Vercel","url":"https://vercel.com/kb/guide/per-environment-and-per-branch-build-commands"},{"title":"Deploying to Vercel without linking a repository — Alex Chan","url":"https://www.alexchantastic.com/deploying-with-vercel-cli"},{"title":"How to use Vercel CLI for deployment - DEV Community","url":"https://dev.to/terieyenike/how-to-use-vercel-cli-for-deployment-361f"},{"title":"Advanced: Vercel Deployment Guide","url":"https://ai-sdk.dev/docs/advanced/vercel-deployment-guide"}]

Based on my search results, here's what I found about the Vercel deploy command flags:

## Vercel Deploy Command Flags

### `--prod` Flag
The `--prod` option flag is used to deploy the project to production for public usage.(no content)When using the `--prod` flag with `vercel build`, the production environment variables will be used instead of the preview environment variables.(no content)By default, Vercel creates a preview deployment. To deploy to your production URL, you run the same command with the `--prod` flag. Note that the production URL that the Vercel CLI outputs isn't actually your set production URL, but it will display the same contents as the production URL.

### Build Environment Variables (`--build-env`)
The Vercel CLI deploy command has the option to pass build environment variables because the build happens at Vercel.(no content)The deploy command processes environment variables from multiple sources and validates their format before deployment. The `addProcessEnv` function handles inheritance of undefined environment variables from the current process, with proper error handling for missing variables.

### Deploy Command Overview
The Deploy Command is the primary user interface for deploying projects to the Vercel platform through the CLI. It orchestrates the entire deployment process from initial project validation through final deployment status reporting, serving as the default command when users invoke the Vercel CLI.

### Additional Flags
The deploy command also supports deploying prebuilt outputs using the `--prebuilt` flag, which requires specific validation and processing.

### Per-Environment Build Commands
For workflows where you need different scripts based on specific environments or branch names, you can create a `vercel.sh` file in your repository that your Build Command uses to run conditional logic.

For complete documentation on all available flags, you can visit the official Vercel CLI deploy documentation at https://vercel.com/docs/cli/deploy.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

content.text:
## VERCEL DEPLOYMENT CONFIG (2025)

### CLI Installation & Commands

```bash
# Install
npm i -g vercel

# Deploy (preview)
vercel
vercel deploy

# Deploy to production
vercel --prod

# Build locally, deploy prebuilt
vercel build
vercel deploy --prebuilt --prod

# Environment variables
vercel env pull                    # Download to .env
vercel env add                     # Add variable
vercel env remove                  # Remove variable
```

### Key Deploy Flags

- `--prod` - Deploy to production (default is preview)
- `--prebuilt` - Deploy pre-built .vercel/output folder
- `--build-env KEY=value` - Pass build environment variables
- `--cwd <path>` - Set working directory
- `--debug` / `-d` - Verbose output

### vercel.json Configuration

```json
{
  "$schema": "https://openapi.vercel.sh/vercel.json",
  
  "buildCommand": "npm run build",
  "devCommand": "npm run dev",
  "installCommand": "npm install",
  "outputDirectory": "dist",
  
  "framework": "nextjs",
  
  "functions": {
    "api/**/*.js": {
      "memory": 3009,
      "maxDuration": 30
    }
  },
  
  "regions": ["iad1", "sfo1"],
  
  "env": {
    "API_URL": "https://api.example.com"
  },
  
  "build": {
    "env": {
      "NODE_ENV": "production"
    }
  },
  
  "headers": [
    {
      "source": "/api/(.*)",
      "headers": [
        { "key": "Access-Control-Allow-Origin", "value": "*" },
        { "key": "Access-Control-Allow-Methods", "value": "GET,POST,PUT,DELETE" }
      ]
    }
  ],
  
  "redirects": [
    {
      "source": "/old-route",
      "destination": "/new-route",
      "permanent": true
    }
  ],
  
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/api/:path*",
      "destination": "https://backend.example.com/api/:path*"
    }
  ],
  
  "git": {
    "deploymentEnabled": {
      "main": true,
      "internal-*": false
    }
  },
  
  "ignoreCommand": "git diff --quiet HEAD^ HEAD ./src"
}
```

### Environment Variables

**Via Dashboard:**
- Project Settings → Environment Variables
- Select environment: Production, Preview, Development
- Redeploy after adding new variables

**Via CLI:**
```bash
vercel env add API_KEY           # Interactive prompt
vercel env pull                  # Download to .env
```

**System Variables (Auto-populated):**
- `VERCEL_ENV` - production/preview/development
- `VERCEL_URL` - Deployment URL
- `VERCEL_GIT_COMMIT_REF` - Git branch
- `VERCEL_GIT_COMMIT_SHA` - Commit SHA

### Build Output API

Standard `.vercel/output` structure:
```
.vercel/output/
├── config.json       # Build configuration
├── static/           # Static assets
└── functions/        # Serverless functions
```

### Breaking Changes (2025)

- **Fluid Compute**: Enabled by default for new projects (April 23, 2025)
- **Glob patterns in git config**: New pattern matching for branch deployment control
- **Vercel CLI 18.0.0+**: Required for `vercel env pull` command

### Framework Auto-Detection

Vercel auto-detects and configures:
- Next.js (recommended)
- Vite
- Remix
- SvelteKit
- Nuxt
- Astro

No vercel.json needed for standard framework setups.

---

**Sources:**
- [Configuring projects with vercel.json](https://vercel.com/docs/project-configuration)
- [vercel deploy](https://vercel.com/docs/cli/deploy)
- [Vercel CLI Overview](https://vercel.com/docs/cli)
- [Environment variables](https://vercel.com/docs/environment-variables)
- [vercel env](https://vercel.com/docs/cli/env)
- [System environment variables](https://vercel.com/docs/environment-variables/system-environment-variables)
- [Deploying Projects from Vercel CLI](https://vercel.com/docs/cli/deploying-from-cli)
